metadata.titel_preek: The Glory of the Living Lord: Epiphany and the Identity of Jesus

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The revelation of Jesus' divine identity and power (Epiphany) as he invades a world occupied by demonic powers to establish his sovereignty.

subject.identificatie: Jesus Christ (The Incarnate Son of God)
tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus’ public ministry begins with his confrontations with the demonic powers.
He utters not an invitation, but a command: 'Follow me.'
Jesus returns in the power of the Spirit... being glorified by all.

object.identificatie: The display of Divine Glory (Doxa) and Authority (Dunamis)
tekstueel_bewijs: The evangelists have made clear that the miraculous cures themselves... are not the central point. What is on display... is the glory of Jesus.

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Holy Spirit
tekstueel_bewijs: At the baptism we have heard the voice of God identifying his Son.
Jesus returned in the power of the Spirit.
The listening church hears of his glory.
Christians need confidence in the identity of our Lord.

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The Evangelists (as witnesses)
tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus returned in the power of the Spirit.
The witnesses to Jesus seek to convey his glory.
The rampaging adversary of God, the would-be destroyer of all of God’s purposes.
The reign of Sin and Death, which holds humankind and all creation in bondage.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is described as a 'usurper' and 'ruler of this world' that requires divine intervention to defeat.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response to the epiphany: following the command and receiving forgiveness.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer / Disciple
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The human action (following) is a direct, almost irresistible effect of the primary subject's (Jesus) command.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God the Father → Divine Glory/Salvation → The Church
actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: Holy Spirit → Jesus Christ ← Sin and Death

voorbeelden_god_subject: Jesus’ public ministry begins with his confrontations.
God brings judgment upon the world.
He is able both to command and to elicit an immediate response.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We need to read the Bible more carefully.
The disciples at table with him in Cana.

voorbeelden: We are meant to be awestruck.
In knowing Jesus as the Son... we come truly to follow him.
He is able both to command and to elicit an immediate response.
With God all things are possible.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon is centered on the 'Power' of the Subject (Jesus) rather than the 'Obligation' of the listener. Grace is presented as the sovereign power of God that creates its own response.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from 'Niet-S1' (the error of mainline denominations) to 'S2' (the reality of the demonic) to 'S1' (the victory of Christ).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the 'Epiphany'—the breaking in of S1 to destroy S2.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; Sin and Death are treated as cosmic powers, not just mistakes.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It explicitly rejects moralism and exemplarism, positioning Jesus as the active Subject who commands and saves.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: He becomes indistinguishable from other prominent religious leaders... no matter how admirable or how worthy of emulation Jesus may be.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: He utters not an invitation, but a command... an offer they can’t refuse.
The incarnate Son of God did not arrive in peaceful neutral territory, but in a world under occupation.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The sermon explicitly attacks the idea of Jesus as a mere example to be emulated.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Jesus is the Lord of the cosmos who acts upon the world, not a model for the world to copy.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; the burden of 'doing' is replaced by the reality of being 'commanded' and 'freed'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic undertones; salvation and discipleship are works of God's power.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The narrative hierarchy is perfectly maintained: the identity of Jesus (Soteriology) strictly precedes and enables the following of the disciples (Ethics).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Christ’s conquest of Satan... participants in his victory over Sin and Death.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit provides the 'Dunamis' for Jesus' ministry and the hearer's response.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; Sin is a 'reign' and 'bondage' that humans cannot escape on their own.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully positions God/Jesus as the Subject of all transformative action, relegating the human hearer to the role of Receiver/Beneficiary.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain current balance as it serves the Epiphany theme.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in grace-oriented actantial structure. It consistently protects the agency of God and avoids the trap of turning the Gospel into a 'to-do' list.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis might focus on the use of Caravaggio or Willimon, Greimas reveals that these are merely 'helpers' to establish the Subject's power.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Nazareth text; Greimas shows that the sermon's 'engine' is the transfer of power from the Sender to the Receiver via the Subject.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that the 'invitation vs. command' distinction is actually a shift from the modal 'Vouloir' (human will) to 'Pouvoir' (divine power).

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Epiphany' season as a semiotic framework to redefine the Subject from 'Teacher' to 'Lord'.
